name: Avoid creating cookie without setting httpOnly option
description: Cross-site scripting attacks often access cookies in an attempt to steal session identifiers or authentication tokens. This is why all major browsers support the HttpOnly cookie property that prevents client-side scripts from accessing the cookie. When HttpOnly is not enabled, attackers may more easily access user cookies. This rule is compliant with OWASP 2013 and 2017 A6 - Sensitive Data Exposure
output:
Line and column for each violation 
Associated value => number of violations found
remediation: Always setting httpOnly option when creating a cookie
total: Number of javascript source codes using express-session

qualityStandards.name: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag
qualityStandards.description: The software uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag.

qualityStandards.name: Sensitive Data Exposure
qualityStandards.description: Many web applications do not properly protect sensitive data, such as credit cards, tax IDs, and authentication credentials. Attackers may steal or modify such weakly protected data to conduct credit card fraud, identity theft, or other crimes. Sensitive data deserves extra protection such as encryption at rest or in transit, as well as special precautions when exchanged with the browser.

qualityStandards.name: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
qualityStandards.description: XSS flaws occur whenever an application includes untrusted data in a new web page without proper validation or escaping, or updates an existing web page with user-supplied data using a browser API that can create HTML or JavaScript. XSS allows attackers to execute scripts in the victim's browser which can hijack user sessions, deface web sites, or redirect the user to malicious sites.
